B-REF	The Loneliness of the Unem-
I-REF	ployed: Social and Political
I-REF	Participation in Germany in a
I-REF	European Context
I-REF	The economic and social crisis highlights the importance of social connections, as they
I-REF	could potentially function as a sort of ”personal safety net“. These connections can provide
I-REF	social support, access to information, informal help or jobs, emotional support (Coleman
I-REF	1990), and may deeply aefct an individual’s ability to cope with job loss or declining
I-REF	incomes. On a social level, political activities, volunteering, helping each other, keeping
I-REF	a promise or telling the truth, are the “cement of society”. It becomes critically important
I-REF	in a social climate of increasing uncertainty and risk. This article focuses on social
I-REF	and political participation indicators, including trust, social meetings, political activities
I-REF	and social isolation. We present Germany in a European context, and also compare the
I-REF	situation of specicfi social groups in Germany. The unemployed are particularly exposed
I-REF	to social isolation: about one out of eight German unemployed have no close friend at
I-REF	all. In addition, they are less likely to be politically active, which reduces their interest
I-REF	representation potentials.
B-REF	There is an increasing recognition among
I-REF	policy-makers that “social connections
I-REF	and relationships” are a key dimension of
I-REF	well-being, reflected for example in the
I-REF	European years of Volunteering (2011) and
I-REF	that of Active Ageing (2012). The report by
I-REF	the “Stiglitz Commission” (Stiglitz, Sen and
I-REF	Fitoussi 2009) includes “social connections
I-REF	and relationships” as one of the dimensions
I-REF	of well-being.
B-REF	The actions of one’s peers and the group
I-REF	norm have a profound influence on indi-
I-REF	vidual’s behaviour, although the impact is
I-REF	not always positive (mafia, gangs). In addi-
I-REF	tion to our immediate connections, there is a
I-REF	more indirect network effect. Eating habits,
I-REF	health attitudes, sex norms are transferred
I-REF	to us through the friends of our friends,
I-REF	and we are influenced by people we do
I-REF	not even know personally (Christakis and
I-REF	Fowler 2009).
B-REF	Social capital can be regarded as a goal in
I-REF	itself, as social relationships, and interper-
I-REF	sonal trust proved to bring happiness to
I-REF	people’s lives (Helliwell 2006). Marriage has
I-REF	the strongest effects (both in a positive and
I-REF	a negative way), but friends tend to be the
I-REF	source of companionship, and are leisure
I-REF	partners (Argyle 1999). People with stronger
I-REF	support networks were found to live longer
I-REF	(ibid, p. 362). People with more friends live
I-REF	longer in part because of the biochemical
I-REF	effects of social isolation, and in part because
I-REF	public health systems are more effective in
I-REF	areas of higher social capital (Stiglitz, Sen et
I-REF	al. 2009). Social isolation is a risk factor for
I-REF	premature death, to nearly the same degree
I-REF	as smoking (Berkman and Glass 2000).
B-REF	Social networks provide (1) social support,
I-REF	(2) social influence, (3) social engagement
I-REF	and attachment, and (4) access to resources
I-REF	and material goods (Berkman et al 2000).
B-REF	Granovetter (1973, 1983) distinguishes
I-REF	between “strong ties” which provide emo-
I-REF	tional support, and “weak ties” (acquain-
I-REF	tances) which have a larger reach, and thus
I-REF	can be more useful with providing infor-
I-REF	mation or access to resources (e.g. jobs) or
I-REF	organizing collective action.
B-REF	ISI 50 – August 2013
I-REF	Seite 7
I-REF	Van Oorschot, Wim, Meuleman, Bart, 2012:
B-REF	Jürgen Kohl, Max-Weber-Institut für
I-REF	Soziologie
I-REF	Ruprecht-Karls-Universität Heidelberg
I-REF	juergen.kohl@soziologie.uni-
I-REF	heidelberg.de
I-REF	Unemployment was shown to have a nega-
I-REF	tive impact on well-being, over and above
I-REF	the income loss (Winkelmann and Winkel-
I-REF	mann 1998). Unemployment hurts, as it
I-REF	harms self-esteem and may bring a loss in
I-REF	personal connections and a sense of aim-
I-REF	lessness. The detrimental effects are likely
I-REF	to be greater in cases where unemployment
I-REF	is involuntary and came unexpectedly.
B-REF	Social connections, especially contacts with
I-REF	employed friends, may help with finding
I-REF	jobs. On the other hand, the company of
I-REF	other workless people may ease the pain of
I-REF	unemployment as joblessness may feel more
I-REF	“normal“ (Clark 2003).
B-REF	This chapter focuses on social and political
I-REF	participation indicators, including (1) trust,
I-REF	(2) political activities, (3) social meetings
I-REF	and (4) social isolation, and discusses these
I-REF	four themes in this sequence. We seek to
I-REF	answer the following questions:
I-REF	– Are there significant differences in the
I-REF	level of social trust across social groups:
I-REF	which groups are the most and least trus-
I-REF	ting in Germany?
I-REF	Figure 1: % of population saying
I-REF	most people can be trusted,
